"E _m_ bun" in Japan encyclopedia, p. 175. was a Japanese era name (年号, nengō, lit. year name) of the Northern Court during the Nanboku-chō period after Bunna and before Kōan. This period started in March 1356 and ended in March 1361;Nussbaum, Kōan, p. 535. The pretender in Kyoto was .Nussbaum, "Go-Kōgon Tennō," p. 255; Titsingh, Isaac. (1834). Annales des empereurs du japon, pp. 302-305. Go-Kōgon's Southern Court rival in Yoshino during this time was .Nussbaum, "Go-Murakami Tennō," p. 257. ==Events of the Enbun era == * 1356 (Enbun 1, 7th month): Minamoto no Michisuke was given the position of naidaijin in the Imperial court hierarchy.Titsingh, p. 303. * 1356 (Enbun 1, 7th month): Ashikaga Yoshinori is raised to the 2nd rank of the 3rd class in the Imperial court hierarchy. * 1357 (Enbun 2, 2nd month): Emperor Go-Murakami released captive Kōgon, Kōmyō and Sukō; and they returned to Kyoto. * 1358 (Enbun 3): Death of Ashikaga Takauji;Titsingh, p. 304. Ashikaga Yoshiakira was appointed as the new shogun.Ackroyd, Joyce.
